ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
management of personal spending, investment, and saving
retirement accounts and tax benefits
mortgages (rent vs. buy)

This course provided a number of tools to manage personal finances. Some of these tools are useful now, many will likely prove useful later in life. While I found the lecturing to be dry at times, the material really is useful and I'm glad to have taken the course. Additionally, the course offered significant opportunity to hone Excel skills.
I developed an economist's perspective on how to manage my individual finances through easily applicable models, and a general understanding of financial offerings I could encounter as I grow older.

I learned a lot about personal finance, including mortgage vs rent, having an after-tax retirement account, stock management, and selection, using credit cards, types of loans (credit card, home equity, student debt, car purchase loans, etc), and general financial planning (how to manage your assets, how to track your spending). Also learned about insurance and annuity offeringstopics that are rarely covered by classes.

I developed insights in various aspects of personal finance, such as the stocks/bonds, ETFs, retirement options, tax advantages, etc. Some of this I had never previously encountered, but even the stuff I had seen, Professor Choi went a lot more in depth and clarified the logical/mathematical models behind certain assumptions.

I learned about the academic research, data, and theory that underpins optimal personal finance decisions in areas of life from choosing a mortgage to building your portfolio. This class improved my ability to use excel and my critical thinking skills. It also helped me evaluate my own personal finances and make a plan for my future so that I can make optimal decisions.
intro to a lot of different useful things, such as mortgages, investing, retirement accounts, tax stuff

Developed excel skills, ability to analysis different types of financial products and the ability to model and structure annuities and run simulations. General information about personal finance was acquired as well.
I learned valuable skills about how to save money before and after retirement. Management was important for me to get more familiar with.
I learned a lot about how to manage my own money, whether that's through the retirement accounts I should open or the rent vs buy debate In housing.

I gained many insights on the finance world and how I would manage others' money (as well as my own) if given the chance. I also learned how to properly optimize investments and take advantage of the tax code.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strength: some pragmatic advice on how to save and invest in your retirement accounts. also debunked some common misconceptions
weaknesses: poorly written problem set assignments and low level of lecture engagement (between the packets and attendance quizzes, felt like grade school again rather than a SOM course)

Strengths are that the lecture slides are generally clear, the problem sets are applicable, and quizzes are just challenging enough. A weakness is that some lectures are a bit dry. Although the professor did warn about this when we got to a particularly dull section on navigating the tax system for example.

The course perfectly balances economic assumptions with cutting-edge research! Case studies provide opportunities to dive further in depth. If anything, problem set takeaways are not easily applicable.

I love the practical nature of the classI have learned so much about personal finances, including topics that I did not know require as much attention from me and topics that I have never heard of before. Professor Choi is a great lecturer (love his pacing and teaching style) and keeps the class interesting with guest speakers. The class is less focused on testing and grades, and more about personal growthyou get as much out of the class as you want from it.

A big weakness of the class is the out-of-class support, especially for homework. Given that homework represents a significant portion of the grade, I expected more support and structure for the class, including office hours. Instead, the TAs seem to be uncomfortable with both the questions and the topic of the PSETs, and Office Hours are done sporadically, at challenging hours (e.g., most happen at 6 PM, right during dinner hours) and announced very late (1-2 days before), making it difficult to try to schedule Office Hours into the day-to-day plan.

Strengths: Professor is very knowledgeable in the subject and goes above and beyond when explaining certain topics of the course.

Weaknesses: Very limited number of office hours for problem sets.

The psets and quizzes were a little hard, but they were intellectually stimulating exercises. I often wished we did more examples in class that applied to the psets, but the material was well distributed through the semester.

This course is very well organized with very comprehensive lectures. The material itself can be dry at times (probably unavoidable when discussing things like taxes), but it is overall well structured to keep students engaged. The *almost* daily pop quizzes help provide incentive to keep up with lecture material and the homeworks offer a chance to go in depth on a topic covered in class.
Very practical stuff in my opinion, my biggest complaint would be that there is no clarity on the grade cutoffs, I really have no idea what grade I'm going to end with

Strengths of the course were that it was engaging, relevant information was provided and their were class speakers that provided different insights from different parts of the field. Sometimes I felt that on the problem sets the wording was a little bit ambiguous which can throw off your calculations and answers and I often had to email TAs for clarification on the wording so that I understood exactly what the questions were asking. This could also be a reflection of my lack of exposure to this type of work previously in my undergraduate career.
Course material was well explained and it was helpful to have quizzes very often to absorb information.

strenghts: very useful information, the lecture notes made following along in class much easier 
weaknesses: some units were a bit rushed for how complicated they are, mainly the taxes portion
Professor Choi and everything about this class was great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
I would not recommend this course unless you have poor personal finance skills or looking for a relatively low-workload course to fill your schedule. The course does push you to think more about your personal finances (great), but most of the information is obvious or may not be relevant (e.g. not having credit card debt or the formulas to calculate thresholds for mortgage refinancing). Other than a few practical pieces of advice, the course offers very minimal intellectual engagement and is poorly structured. Attending lectures and reading the slides packet are basically interchangeable. Professor Choi is a decent lecturer, but he has poorly written problem sets. The problem sets confuse students not due to the difficulty of the content, but rather the wording and inconsistencies in terminology. Many of the TF OH questions were just clarification questions on the writing. The course is also incredibly rigid and runs through exam week for undergraduates. This is stated upfront, and I would recommend students not underestimate the inconvenience that this causes when considering the course.

All else aside, the worst part of the course was the quizzes. I assume that the purpose of having beginning-of-the-class period quizzes is to encourage lecture attendance and see if students have an understanding of the materials. The quizzes accomplish both--however, poorly. Yes, twice the amount of students shows up in quiz lectures than in non-quiz lectures. However, some students leave right after the quiz, and lecture participation is no better even with more people. Students who attend regularly, but a missed quizzes due to unforeseen conflicts fare worse than students who show up for the first 10 minutes. Moreover, reading the lecture notes briefly vs. paying attention in class results in the same level of preparedness for quizzes since the questions are either common sense or specific to one bullet point on a slide that you happen to flip to. Life happens, so know that there are better classes out there where students are not graded on having perfect attendance. Class quizzes are stated directly on the syllabus, so it's perfectly fair. However, I would caution students to carefully consider whether taking a mediocre course is worth dealing with glorified attendance quizzes.
Yes, I have already recommended some friends to take this course. I find the material to be very beneficial and helpful to planning my life's financial plan.
This course will assure that you make wise decisions with your money! It's a no-brainer for everyone, even those outside the ECON major.

I would definitely recommend the class for students who are interested in Personal finance skills; the class exceeds expectations in terms of content and relevance to my day-to-day life. The class also helps build on and apply economic concepts (like tax shields, discounting, and PV) on very tangible issues like mortgages, renting a home, credit card debt, and other aspects of daily life. Overall would recommend for anyone interested to develop their personal finance management skills.

I would recommend this as an econ elective for other students, especially seniors. The psets tended to be quite hard (had to go to office hours or really look over class slides), but the SOM students said the same. The daily quizzes were a little annoying, but definitely do-able as they were open note and short. Professor Choi is super well connected, and if you want to gain insight on being a professor or being able to meet the guest lecturers, this is a great class to take. Overall, I learned a lot about the practical aspects of personal finance and implemented parts of it in my own life.

Yes, this course is incredibly practical. You will learn things that are directly (and at times immediately) applicable to your life. This course has helped remove a lot of the mystery surrounding how I should handle my personal finances. The pop quizzes can be somewhat difficult at times, but the class is overall great.
yeah, i think it's good stuff to know just as a financially independent adult
I would recommend this to any student looking to learn more about personal finance, attain more literacy, learn from different perspectives and develop excel skills.
Yes, everyone is better off gaining information on how to manage their income and other expenses.
Def, very pertinent class. You'll save some money by learning tricks you didn't know, but the key is to increase revenue first.

Yes, it gives very helpful information that would be difficult to learn all on your own. You get a structured environment to learn some essential personal finance information with a very knowledgeable professor
Very very practical, James is a great professor
